topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Emilie previews a highly tactical PR conversation; Lenny introduces Emilie’s background (Uber, Box) and what they’ll cover, including targeting publications, pitching reporters, and real pitch examples.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for Sprig (product insights) and Eppo (experimentation platform), followed by Lenny welcoming Emilie to the show.

topics.title: Is press worth it for startups?
topics.summary: They discuss why press often doesn’t directly drive signups, but creates second-order benefits like credibility, sales enablement, recruiting leverage, and partner validation—especially for B2B.

topics.title: When PR drives growth in B2C
topics.summary: Emilie explains when press can create immediate consumer growth (e.g., Perplexity) due to low friction and easy-to-understand value, contrasting with B2B’s longer conversion path.

topics.title: Affiliate marketing and product review coverage
topics.summary: They unpack affiliate-driven press (commission-based product review links) and how many consumer brands rely on it versus traditional earned media features.

topics.title: Fundraising announcements: when and how to pitch
topics.summary: Emilie argues funding stories are usually coverable if pitched correctly, especially to TechCrunch: be concise, offer an exclusive, pattern-match to the right beat, and follow up respectfully with new info.

topics.title: Which publications to target and why
topics.summary: A tactical rundown of major outlets and what they’re good for: TechCrunch (funding/product, ecosystem), Axios (deal-focused), Business Insider (pitch decks/metrics/lists), VentureBeat (AI), Fast Company (future of work/design/op-eds), Forbes (awards/contributors).

topics.title: NYT, WSJ, CNBC: realistic expectations
topics.summary: They cover why top-tier outlets rarely feature early-stage startups unless there’s major scale, hard metrics, valuation transparency, or controversy; more often you’ll appear as a quote in a broader trend piece.

topics.title: Managing risk: controlling message vs editorial control
topics.summary: Emilie explains you can’t control angles, only correct factual errors; the best defense is strong spokesperson prep and repeated, clear messaging to influence what sticks with the reporter.

topics.title: Finding podcasts, newsletters, and awards to pitch
topics.summary: Emilie shares a practical process: search by customer vertical, validate fit (guest types, activity, quality), ask customers what they consume, and start outreach with a lightweight “open to guest ideas?” message.

topics.title: Warm intros vs cold outreach to reporters
topics.summary: They argue relationships mainly help get a reply, not coverage; cold outreach can be equally effective given fast-changing beats and media formats, as long as pitches are thoughtful and relevant.

topics.title: How to reach reporters and write effective pitches
topics.summary: Emilie recommends a multi-channel approach (email, X/Twitter, DMs, LinkedIn), ultra-clear subject lines and intent, ~3-sentence pitches, respectful follow-ups, pointing out coverage gaps, and offering contrarian viewpoints when appropriate.

topics.title: Positioning: take on incumbents, avoid category creation
topics.summary: Emilie advises framing startups against known incumbents to give reporters instant context, and warns that “category creation” language usually fails in PR pitches even if it may work elsewhere.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor read for Vanta (trust management and compliance automation), then the conversation tees up upcoming real pitch examples.
